articles.headline: France, Unlike U.S., Is Deep Into Stimulus Projects
articles.snippet: France plans to spend 75 percent of its stimulus money this year; the U.S. is unlikely to accomplish that until late 2010.
articles.abstract: France plans to spend 75 percent of its stimulus money this year; the U.S. is unlikely to accomplish that until late 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: FONTAINEBLEAU, France  French workers normally take off much of the summer, but this month, there is something of a revolution going on here at this former royal chateau roughly 30 miles southeast of Paris. The throngs of tourists will be jostling alongside stonemasons, restoration experts and other artisans paid by the French government’s $37 billion economic stimulus program.

articles.headline: Venture Capitalists Look for a Return to the A B C’s
articles.snippet: As returns on venture capital have sunk since the dot-com boom years, some in the industry believe there are too many investment dollars chasing too few “next big ideas.”
articles.abstract: As returns on venture capital have sunk since the dot-com boom years, some in the industry believe there are too many investment dollars chasing too few “next big ideas.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For a group accustomed to looking outward for the next big thing, Silicon Valley’s venture capitalists are getting very introspective these days.

articles.headline: In a Downturn, Jewelers Aren’t So Precious
articles.snippet: Consumers are spending less on jewelry, and the industry is feeling the pinch.
articles.abstract: Consumers are spending less on jewelry, and the industry is feeling the pinch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a different economy, Billy Mitchell and Nicole Drucker of San Francisco might have splurged on a $10,000 engagement ring. But Ms. Drucker is out of work and they need to save for a house. So in April, Mr. Mitchell got down on one knee on the Golden Gate Bridge and proposed with a $4,000 diamond ring he had bought on the Internet.

articles.headline: Automakers’ Swift Cases in Bankruptcy Shock Experts
articles.snippet: The sales raised the profile of a tactic once used primarily to shed failing plants or unneeded equipment, and was not considered until recently as a substitute for a complete restructuring.
articles.abstract: The sales raised the profile of a tactic once used primarily to shed failing plants or unneeded equipment, and was not considered until recently as a substitute for a complete restructuring.

articles.headline: Ex-Worker Said to Steal Goldman Code
articles.snippet: Sergey Aleynikov masterminded a dazzling bank theft, the authorities say, and he did it without brandishing a gun or cracking a vault.
articles.abstract: Sergey Aleynikov masterminded a dazzling bank theft, the authorities say, and he did it without brandishing a gun or cracking a vault.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is no John Dillinger, no public enemy No. 1. But Sergey Aleynikov nonetheless masterminded a dazzling bank theft, the authorities say, and he did it without brandishing a gun or cracking a vault.

articles.headline: Obama Resets Ties to Russia, but Work Remains
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Russia declared a rapprochement in part by agreeing to disagree on important issues.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Russia declared a rapprochement in part by agreeing to disagree on important issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  President Obama kicked off a new chapter in Russian-American relations with significant progress on several fronts during a two-day visit to the nation that began Monday. About a year after the relationship ruptured over the war in Georgia, the two sides are now back at the table and doing business.

articles.headline: U.S. Considers Curbs on Speculative Trading of Oil
articles.snippet: Reacting to swings in oil prices, regulators said they were considering limits on “speculative” energy traders.
articles.abstract: Reacting to swings in oil prices, regulators said they were considering limits on “speculative” energy traders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Reacting to the violent swings in oil prices in recent months, federal regulators announced on Tuesday that they were considering new restrictions on “speculative” traders in markets for oil, natural gas and other energy products.
